availability.p: This image and transcription is publicly accessible. The image appears courtesy of the repository named in the Source Description. The transcription and annotation were undertaken by Kentucky Historical Society staff, volunteers, and interns. If referencing this document title, accession number, and permanent URL.

seriesStmt.title: Civil War Governors of Kentucky Digital Documentary Edition

msIdentifier.repository: Kentucky Department for Libraries and Archives
msIdentifier.collection: Office of the Governor, Beriah Magoffin: Governor's Official Correspondence File, Petitions for Pardons and Remissions, 1859-1862

body.p:
To His Excellency Beriah Magoffin
Governor of Kentucky

Your Petitioner William McKaye -- respectfully states that at the January Term (1861) of the city court of Louisville he was fined fifty dollars for carrying concealed a pistol. He confessed Judgment. He states that the pistol was found on his person, during the Christmas holiday -- that he is not in the habit of carrying concealed weapons, and that no person was injured by reason of his carrying the weapon, and that he did not attempt to injure any person with it. He states that he got the same from his house, and loaded it with powder only and fired it off -- as hundreds of other youngsters were doing at the same time in this city, celebrating Christmas -- and a policemen not friendly with him took it from him, and he was fined. He has paid $15 75. the costs in the prosecution, and that is all he his able to pay -- He respectfully, asks your Excellency to remit said fine & he will ever pray & --

The petitioner Wm McKaye -- is a young man, we know him well, and believe that a fine should not have been assessed against him under the circumstances as stated in his petition & ask for a remission of the fine.

Isham Talbot
A Batschelet
Michael Dietz
Jacob Pfalzer
John Mangold
J, Connell J P J C
W G Reasor
Wm Troxler
G H Ditcher
Will H Fagan
J. M Campbell
M. Pyles
D, W, Henderson
